children.text: Learn Persian with Chai in Conversation, "Growing Up Neemrooni: Interview with Sierra Urich, director of the movie Joonam."

Salaam behamegi, welcome to Growing Up Neemrooni, where we talk to prominent members of the Iranian diaspora community. I'm your host, Leyla Shams. Today, we're talking to Sierra Urich, director of the movie, Joonam.

As you'll hear in the interview, I recently watched this movie and absolutely loved it. I cannot recommend it more highly. But to begin this discussion and give you some context into Sierra, I'm going to read her director's statement about the movie:

Here, it is important to make a distinction between Joonam as a film about the Iranian experience, and Joonam as a film of the Iranian diasporic experience. Of the phenomenon of "diaspora" in a Persian context, Amy Malek writes, "As Iranian community formation began to coalesce around the world, Iranians who may have once self-identified as living in exile (tab'id) no longer thought of themselves only through reference to Iran and their new home – that quintessential binary of exile –but also through their dispersed kin, friends, and networks in Iranian communities in Los Angeles, Toronto, London, Sydney, and beyond" (Malek, 26). This cultural shift is important to note as we learn, through the interview, how community coalesced around Urich's film, bringing Urich closer to her heritage, her family, and the Iranian diaspora through the artmaking process.

"We can't go to Iran, it's too dangerous. Maybe one day the political situation will get better. As a child, I took this family refrain at face value. Growing up in rural Vermont in an English-speaking household, my mother's memories were the only window I had to understand my cultural identity. Visiting Iran was never on the table, and because of that, I grew up without much connection to it. My father was American, my friends were American, and I was American. The fact that my mother was from Persia, as she preferred me to say, an ancient empire absent from modern maps, was just a fun fact that made me feel exotic and mysterious. But in reality, for me, Iran was just food and holidays. Anything more was out of reach. Joonam was born out of my deep, dormant, and unresolved desire to feel connected to Iran. Today, Iran is on the cusp of another revolution, and this time the fight for freedom is being led by women and girls. These last few months, I have been glued to the news in my social media feed, moved by the images of resistance and unimaginable bravery coming out of the country, and heartbroken to witness the horrific crackdown against young people asking for basic human rights. Iranians are fighting not only to liberate a country, but also an entire culture. And for Iranians living in the diaspora, this has seismic implications. The yearning that compelled me to make this film was born from the same profound desire, a longing to inherit more than exile from our families, a longing for home, a longing for our very identities."
And with that, let's get on to the interview. So Sierra Urich, thank you so much for talking with me today.
Yeah, thank you. I'm super excited to be here.
Me too. So I actually--well, first I'm so sorry about your grandmother. I saw that she passed away last year. I'm sorry.
Thank you. Yeah.
It was such a joy to watch her on film and then seeing that bit at the end was, really I'm glad you guys got to do that project before that happened.

Yeah, me too, it was a good--yeah, I don't think I realized that I was spending the last five years of her life filming her, but I'm so happy that I got to spend all this time with her because of this project when I probably wouldn't have spent as much time.
Yeah. So what was the timeline of the project? And when did you stop filming?

Yeah, so it was about five years now, just as a yeah, from start to finish. And most of the filming happened in 2019 over a summer spent with my mother and grandmother, but filming happened on either side of that year. 2018, we did a little bit. I did a couple other pickup shoots in 2020 and 2021. So it was a long, sort of a long meandering process.
Right. And at the end, it included some clips from the protests that are happening. So then that kind of threw me off. So did you go in and add those in later?

These "conversations sparked in the diaspora" and suddenly brought into the open, could be seen as happening in solidarity with protests in the homeland, but could also be understood as a kind of willingness to perceive or be perceived as (identified with) a certain identity, in this case an Iranian one, now that there is something diasporic Iranians wish to identify with. In other words, they find themselves "...where identities are negotiated in response to geopolitical and cultural shifts through diasporic practices and experiences of belonging, processes that Lok Siu has described as diasporic citizenship (Siu 2005, p.5)" (Malek, 29). I am reminded of my Bibi (my grandma, born in Iran) whose disgust with American culture motivates her refusal to become a citizen of the United States, and further, to identify herself as American, despirte her residential status here for most of her adult life. To be a citizen of a place is an act of self determination, just as adopting any identity signifier is.

I was editing when the protests started really taking off in Iran. So as we were putting together the final structure of the film, every night, I would go home and just kind of scroll through what was happening. And I mean, it was like, yeah, so many feelings came up from that. But you know, it was really interesting for me to also see how that was sparking conversation in the diaspora and all these things I've been thinking about over the last five years about my identity and, you know, lack of accessibility to Iran and by proxy what felt like, you know, lack of accessibility to my identity. And now everyone is trying to have these conversations out in the open because of these, you know, really moving, brief protests. And so all of that was really going on while we were editing, but really sort of landed me in this place after wading through these feelings over the last five years.

Yeah, it's incredible. I have never gotten so many messages from people who have grown up in the diaspora and have felt disconnected exactly what you're saying, and all of a sudden, you know, want to learn Persian and you were a little bit ahead of the curve. A lot of people that suddenly came up for them now. But moving back, so we started it that way. I have a ton of questions for you. This is going to be a four hour conversation. But I first wanted to say I got an email about this movie Joonam that you directed. So we're talking about Joonam that was just premiered at Sundance. Is that right?
Yep.

Wow. Premiered at Sundance. And so I got an email about it and I'd seen, you know, things about it, you know, on social media and I read there was a large showing of Iranian female directors in Sundance this year. There were three films, I believe. Right?
Yeah. Mhm.

I was struck by this admission from Leyla---that her subjective experience in relation to trauma, or exposure to other people's trauma, made her hesitant (or paralyzed, even) as she approached engagement with another's voice, another's mode of self expression. At a certain point, can oversaturation with regards to connection--in this case, Leyla's podcast practice, her interviews and language courses, this act of generosity---lead to lack of engagement with, or listening to, others' public and private turmoil? And then how do we resist the temptation to shut down our listening, and persist in making and engaging with art?

But I was very, like, I got the link and I was very resistant to watch it. I have to say, because I read the description and I was like, oh, man, it's it's been such a hard few months for all of us. And like all this trauma, we all have this like trauma from our families. We all have these, like, stories. Like I cannot watch another like trauma filled movie about what's going on in like people's identity crisises. So I didn't watch it until two days ago. I've been preparing this interview, like I kept putting it off. And oh, my goodness, I have to say it was such an incredible experience watching your movie. I loved it. I loved it. And sometimes, you know, there's art that you come upon and it just makes you excited about life and excited about art and the possibilities of filmmaking and making art and I, I really was, like, tearing up--I'm kind of like getting emotional now--I was like tearing up through half the movie because I was like, oh, this is like why we have movies. So I really appreciate that you made this. It was so beautiful.

Abbas Kiarostami is an Iranian filmmaker who is largely considered one of the greatest of all time. The Criterion Channel describes his work as "poised delicately between fiction and documentary...poignant, self-reflexive." Joonam certainly follows in Kiarostami's footsteps as a documentary film that is focused on storytelling and the search for meaning or truth within the human condition, ultimately understanding our inevitable subjectivity, our separate truths---that beauty is found in the sharing of our individual worlds and perspectives.

And it reminded me a lot of, the whole time I was watching it, the pacing is just so lovely. It's, there's a lot of silence. There's a lot of, just being, which is so hard to do. And it reminded me of Kiarostami.
Wow, thank you. Oh, my God.

This is another way in which the artmaking process allows for connection across time and space for people of the diaspora--working within an artistic, cultural tradition, which exists in Sierra's very DNA. Her mother, Mitra, is a painter and visual artist interested in the blending of traditional art styles with contemporaneity. This blending, I'd argue, is another form of listening, of sama.
It reminded me of like the great like Iranian cinema that I've seen, and that I really like. I really feel like you channeled that. So I just wanted to start with that. It's an incredible movie.
Wow. Thank you.

An example of how generational trauma effects both the artmaker and audience. Our expectations of art from others who have similar backgrounds are informed by the projection of our own trauma (which, though all encompassing, at times, is not reflective of the complete human condition).

And even though it like goes through difficult subjects and you know, there is, there's talk of trauma and all this stuff, it's not like a depressing movie. It's really lovely to watch. And this place that you live, in Vermont. Where is that in Vermont, by the way? What city is it?
It's like sort of central northern Vermont about half hour south of Berlin.

Okay. But the city is like a big character in the movie, too. So that was really fun to see just the countryside and the silence there and the seasons there. And you can kind of see everything going on. So yeah. So let's just start with that. I encourage everybody to watch this movie. I'm super excited about it. And exactly like what you're saying like that ties in exactly to what's going right now so it couldn't be more timely.
Levity and humor in our art, or at least the incorportation and inclusion of varied elements of the human condition, seem like a potential balm for the previously mentioned fear.

Yeah. Well, thank you. I mean, thank you for saying that. That is like the highest praise you could have possibly given me. And I wanted this film to connect with other Iranians, other like neemroonis, other half Iranians, other people who are maybe an immigrant themselves or a child of an immigrant. So the fact that it connected with you and that it didn't just make you feel super depressed is, you know, the highest possible thing I was hoping to achieve. And it is sort of a funny movie. And it was supposed to be funny and it was supposed to be lighthearted and dealing with, you know, complex identity issues as well. But it's like Iranian women are hilarious, witty, full of joy and love. And so I wanted to capture that about my grandmother and my mother and our dynamic. And so I really wanted a movie that wasn't just about our trauma, but was about the full dynamic in Iranian American families, how it can be so layered and full of joy.

Completely, completely. And I guess let's go back. There were a lot of flashbacks in the movies that showed like you growing up in Vermont. Let's go back to your childhood. Where were you born? What was your childhood like?

I was actually born in Rhode Island, but my family moved to Vermont when I was just a baby. And so they still live in the house that they moved to 30 years ago. And I grew up in kind of a rural town in the foothills of the Green Mountains of Vermont and really identified with Vermont growing up and with my friends and, you know, we didn't speak Farsi in the home. My father is not Iranian.
Gary Joon. Gary Joon.
Gary Joon. Exactly.

He's this very sweet background figure in the movie. You just see him popping up every once in a while just quietly doing his own thing. "Just half of my beer, half of my beer here. I don't know what you guys are talking about. You ladies are crying over there."

That's the dynamic for sure. And my mother didn't speak Farsi because she didn't want to exclude him. When you're in a household where only one member speaks a language, it really takes a lot of effort to just continually speak that language even if the other people in the house can't understand. And so it was just natural that we all spoke English at home.
Were there any Iranians in the town?
Great context for Sierra's career as a filmmaker, and her later wish to connect with her heritage and Iranian identity.

Vermont doesn't have a ton of Iranians. I think we had a couple family friends a few towns over, but no one that I personally could identify with as another kid. And it was pretty sparse. No one in our town was an Iranian. There was no one really that was super close in our life besides my extended family who was a few states over. And so I think for me being Iranian was always something that was my mother's identity, but not mine. And feeling connected to it through her, but knowing that, okay, this is the family that I'm a part of, but it's really her thing and I'm just like her child. And so it gets to be mine through that, but nothing more. So that's really where I was coming from just growing up and also where I was coming to with this film.
So then did she teach you any words or what was your relationship with Iranian culture in general? Like you did Nowruz or you did...

Distance from a culture, or the inability to speak a language, can make it difficult to celebrate a or partake in tradition. Here's an excertpt from the beginning of my companion essay: "Sitting in my Austin apartment, surrounded by real plants I’ve let die and a fake Christmas tree which will never die, which decorates the corner of our living room year-round, much to the chagrin of my roommate, I study the picture of my Khaleh Lilly’s haft-seen table, standing beautiful and golden and alone, like a statue or monument. "Sorry—the picture came first," my Khaleh Sholeh, Lilly’s daughter, messaged me on Whatsapp four days ago now, as if the explanation that follows is necessary context for how I should look, or listen, if I do. Amoo Moostafa’s heart attack, the family gathered round him in the ICU for many days of this thirteen-day New Year, prayerful, his body golden as the tongue of a grandfather clock—saa’at—I imagine; Khaleh Lilly’s own Parkinsons, which shakes her image when she video calls, and makes it impossible for her to write this message to me herself, though she’s one of the few family members I have who speaks nearly perfect English; Khaleh Shadi and Uncle Siamak’s bankruptcy and pending divorce; the ongoing genocide in Palestine and Netanyahu’s and Trumps promises for all-out war with the Islamic regime; Nina and Great-Grandma Joon already dead and buried, never to have met me; Papa and Bibi kept from their home and their family in my same state of Texas, going on six years now, exiled by fear, and alone this Nowruz—all of which made celebrating an impossible task for my family. All of us belonging to one another, all of us feeling this ache."

Yeah, we did Nowruz. My mom tried to teach me Farsi, I think in more inconsistent ways of teaching me a few words here and there, or she had some classes at home that she would teach me a few words with friends, but nothing consistent enough to really have it be a fluent language that I was speaking at home.
Were you interested when you were a kid?

The Persian language, like going to Iran, or finding a romantic partner, or a brother or mother, or publishing my writing, became an obsession or challenge—an attempt to find external validation and affirmation, to fill the gaping, human (and universal, yet achingly personal) longing and loneliness I felt inside me my entire life. I realize now that I was more like a Pirate of Persian—looting, fighting against the ocean storms of my mind, black sail raised, traveling with no real direction, no sense of home. Every mistake weathering me, a new scar or tattoo on my heart, further isolating me from my identity, from my heritage, my grief. In seeking perfection of the mouth, of self-expression, I was leaving myself the same way I was convinced everyone had left me, my voice reaching out, swallowed by the storm.

No, I was not interested. You know, I think my friends didn't speak Farsi. It was only my aunts and my uncles and my other cousins, maybe a few of my cousins did, but the ones that I was really close to weren't fluent either. And so I was embarrassed. I didn't want to speak a language that I didn't know how to speak. I felt embarrassed about people making a fuss over it if I did say a word. The family is so excited and they're so excited when you say something. I was just shy and I didn't want to be, you know, fussed over. So I really rejected it as a kid.
Okay. And then what about the food or anything like that? Was that a part of your upbringing?

Food as an expression of diasporic longing, both for immigrants and children of immigrants, and as an act of community and communion, is extremely prevalent in the global Iranian community. "Thus the pleasure derived from eating abgusht conveys both commensality, as a collective cultural practice, and an individual appropriation of enjoyment. The incompatible public and private appropriation of the dish as the object of pleasure conferred on the term lazatt conflicting meanings that made abgusht eating as a «home-going» fraught with tension." (Sanadjian, 99).

Yeah, my mom's a fantastic cook. And so the food was a huge part of the upbringing. Fesenjoon, Gormeh Sabzi, Ash Reshteh. That was, you know, some of my favorites. But I always felt surface level in those ways for me where we celebrate Nowruz, I eat Persian food, I have this big family and they're so much fun. But it's kind of like the costuming of being Iranian without really feeling like, oh, this truly is something that's me. Yeah, exactly.
Right. And so you were four years old when your grandmother came from Iran. Is that right?
Yep. Exactly.
Okay. But she didn't live in the same town as you.
No. They didn't live in the same town. They lived a few states over there in Massachusetts.
Okay. So then what was your relationship with her like growing up and with your grandparents? Because they couldn't speak English at all when you were little, right?

I'd argue that terms which are prevelant yet unnamed in this conversation thus far would be the "language barrier" and "language proficiency" and/or "fluency." Perhaps the conversation here could be seen as contradicting the argument I make in the two essays I've written that accompany and comment on this transcript---that there are ways of listening beyond semantic understanding, and that language proficiency is not a prerequisite to having a relationship, to loving someone. Or maybe seen a different way, both of these ways of being are valuable; both knowing and unknowing can swing open the doors of meaning. As ethnomusicologist Jean During writes, "the effect of sama [listening] reaches its climax when the five components of being contribute to hearing: temperament, the soul, intellect ('aql), the heart and the spirit. (Some Sufis add to this the body, which expresses itself among other things in dance.)" (During, 133).

No, and I was frustrated by them when I was little. It was like, who are these people that have just showed up in my life and they can't talk to me and my mom is making them take care of me while she's at work. And this is annoying. And I can't, you know, I can't communicate it any better because I'm only four years old. And so I think I was really annoyed for a while as a kid of like, just frustrated by the barrier of language. And they were somewhat unknown entities to me, I think in the beginning of my life. And then of course, as I got older, they're just a fixture, just a fixture of you know, my grandparents, but it was always surface level. You know, it's like, these are the people that I know love me who I, and I love them. And there's these terms of endearment that I know, but otherwise, I don't really know who they are. Or we can't have a really in-depth conversation.
Right. Were you close to your father's grandparents at all?

No, my father's parents actually died when he was young. So I never knew them. And my father's family is still a little bit more distant. And so they were, my father's side was never a huge part of our lives, except for a couple of people. So it was really my extended family was my mother's side.
Right. And you had a small family. It's just you, right? You're an only child. Okay, me too.
Yeah, definitely.

Did you get like annoyed by their kind of affectionate outpouring as well, your mom's side of the family? Because there's a lot of, you know, Tawrof in Iranian families and like a lot of like, ghorboonet beram, and pinching cheeks and just very physical, physicality and stuff like that. So was that annoying to you? Or was it?
It's funny that you asked that. I think it probably was, because it's just so much like in your space. And I was definitely a shy kind of kid.
And you're in rural Vermont where everything's just like far apart. And like these people are, you know?

Yeah. I think it was because we didn't live near them. It was kind of like a spectacle for me. Every time we would go to hang out with the extended family, it was like, I live in this small town. There's only three of us. It's very quiet. And now here's my family and it's like intense and everyone's shouting and grabbing each other and kissing each other. And there's food everywhere and everyone's talking with their mouth open. And I was just like, whoa, what is this?

And what about your mom? Like, would she have this like shift when like when she was speaking English with you in Vermont versus like when she was speaking Persian with her family and stuff? Would you see her as like a different person or how did that work?

Language in association to identity and self determination is poignant here. Despite Mitra's public hesitation to identify with her Persian heritage, and fierce individualism, a private wish exists in her for her daughter to refer to her in the language of her origins. This seems to split her into two identities, where it contributes to Sierra's identity entire.

Yeah, exactly. It was like my mother is the one at home. And then when I, when she's with her extended family, I'm seeing her as like Iranian Mitra. My mom's name is Mitra. And suddenly it was like, oh, she's a, she's a sister. She's a daughter. She's speaking in this language that I can't understand. And so every time it was sort of like she was just these two people for me. Yeah. And it's funny, you know, my mom, I obviously call my mom, "mom." But every once in a while, when I'll say "Maman," she has expressed to me that it makes her feel like a mom in a new way, because that's what she's used to calling her mom. And so it's sort of like this split personality, I think, for her and for me, where there's the American English speaking mom that I sort of identify with or have built a relationship with. And then there's the Persian Mitra, and I guess the Persian mom that I haven't always felt super--I'm not sure if "connected to" is the right word, but just it's like a different relationship that I haven't necessarily fostered and one that she's not always used to. You know, I don't call her "Maman." So.
So then so you grew up and you went to RISD. Is that right? For your undergrad?
Yup. Mhm.
So throughout that time, was there any changes or when did the spark happen when you all of a sudden thought, oh, I should start learning Persian? Yeah. Talk about young adulthood.

This exemplifies the divergence between first and second generation Iranian Americans. "While early first-generation Iranian Americans often chose to go by names like Mike or Mo, or disclaimed Iranian heritage in favor of Italian or ambiguously Mediterranean ones during the heights of U.S.-Iranian hostilities, the second generation does not appear to be undertaking the same degree of «covering» strategies as did their parents (Tehranian 2008). There is in fact some indication that the second generation is instead organizing and advocating for their rights to cultural belonging as Iranian Americans in the United States" (Malek, 29). Mitra's "covering" or wish to protect Sierra from her heritage is at odds with Sierra's wish to seek out and embrace her "Persianness" or her Iranian identity.

Young adulthood. Yeah. I went to, I went to the Rhode Island School of Design and studied art and found my way to filmmaking there. And then after I, and I don't think, you know, my like Iranian identity, it still didn't really feel personal to me then. You know, I think this was post-9/11. I was in elementary school when 9/11 happened. I remember my mom telling me very specifically, like, say you're Persian, not Iranian, because, you know, Iran is going to be associated with this place, and I don't want you to be subject to that, you know, xenophobia or racism.
Right. And so I think, in looking back, do you think that that was true or do you think that it was like her own trauma, like causing her to think that?

The curation of how one might be percieved has interesting implications for both Urich's filmmaking process and her identity formation (two aspects of her life that are perhaps inextricable). It is a question of self expression, of listening, and of silence. An interesting complication is introduced, too, when one's cultural and familial history becomes important to that mode of genuine or sincere self expression, and when that self expression could have implications on the safety and security of a beloved. Afsaneh Najmabadi contends with this in her book 'Familial Undercurrents, writing: "Telling these stories is “to retrieve a past that is ours but not ours alone.” What right did I have to write my parents’ story when they had chosen silence?"" (Najmabadi, 1).

I think it was more her thing that she, you know, I mean, I'm sure part of it was true, but her stance has always been protection. That, you know, be really careful about how you present yourself to the world because that will have ramifications for you. And I think that's very Iranian of, carefully curate how you are perceived because that will matter for your life. And in a lot of ways, it'll matter for your safety. And so I think that's how, where she's coming, where she had been coming from and where she is often coming from.
Yeah. Right. And one of my favorite scenes in the movie is exactly this, what you're saying, is your mom arguing her thoughts on this.
Yeah.
Spoilers, though.
Yeah.

And so, and you in general, like you're, you could pass as American. So were you, is that how it was or did you ever feel "other" when you were like in college, for example, or did you feel like you kind of blended in?
Hmm. I think I felt like I blended in. I didn't necessarily, I didn't feel a lot of, I didn't feel a lot of othering growing up, whether that was happening to me or not. I wasn't aware of it.
Right.

And in college, sort of the same thing. And I think that has sort of, you know, overwhelmingly been my experience, I would say up until now, which it's sort of transformed a little bit, but feeling actually like, I am not from an immigrant family. You know, I didn't, I didn't really see my mom in that light. I just saw her as my mom who was maybe like a little weird and different, you know, as a kid, I was like, "oh yeah, she's not like my other friend's moms." But I didn't think about that in terms of her identity or her immigrant status or the fact that she's from Iran. I just thought, "Oh, this is a fun fact. My mom's from Iran and she wears makeup and the rest of my mom's friends wear fleece." You know, it wasn't really, I didn't, we didn't speak a different language at home. And when in school, I just felt like I identify with my friends and my community and it feels the same as it does at home, and my mom's a little weird.
Right.

And, and that's kind of the overwhelming feeling that I had throughout my life until Iran started to become a little bit more, I'd say like in the cultural like news cycle. And then I was playing with that as a young adult of, you know, this is part of my identity. Do I acknowledge it? Do I not acknowledge it? Am I using this as like currency to seem kind of exotic and interesting and cool in college? You know, I kind of played with, you know, what is this thing? Without really investigating it further. Just being like, oh, you know, maybe if I say I'm Iranian, I'll come across kind of edgy, you know?
Interesting. Okay. Yeah.
Yeah. And it wasn't until I was more of a young adult and had graduated that I started to feel more of a pull to feel a personal connection to Iran.
And how did that happen? What was the, yeah, was there a spark or it was just a gradual.

Just by virtue of Sierra’s presence and willingness to listen, she had scaled the “language barrier” (language barrier: a phrase I loathe somewhat—all of us battering against the gates, begging for someone else to let us through. What if we renamed this? Reoriented ourselves to the mystery and possibilities of communion? Of being with? Language horizon. Language ocean. Language garden. A mystery we wade into with humility, hope, with the intention to listen). Just by virtue of Behjat’s making sound, making music, and trusting in Sierra’s love for her to create or find meaning beyond or hidden by what we typically think of as “language” (language as a semantic mode, as a barrier), meant her voice, her song, wouldn’t only be heard, but sought after, listened for—felt.

I think it was a natural gradual interest of, you know, wishing that I could talk to my grandmother and her being embarrassed that I couldn't speak the language. And, you know, over time you go to family functions or, you know, various events and people introduce themselves to you in Farsi and then you can't really do it back, and it's embarrassing. And, you know, automatically, they kind of, it's natural, you end up kind of being on the outside, you know, if someone can't have a conversation with you, they say, "Oh, okay." You know, it's very sweet, but then they kind of move away from you. And so I think I was just feeling a little bad about the fact that I wasn't as connected. And around the same time, my mom ends up calling me while I'm at this art residency, actually working on this other experimental short film piece, and so I had a zoom recorder with me at the time, and so she calls me because my grandmother is trying to open up, but in her older age with all these stories that she had never heard before. And so I was already in this place of like questioning my connection to Iran and wanting to speak Farsi. And then my mom sort of calls and beckons me home with these stories from my grandmother. And it was like, oh, you know, maybe I should really follow this trail because it just seems like the right place in the right time. And yeah, this film began from a much more, I'd say, like naive place where I was just interested in these stories, interested in this place that had always been so exoticized for me and just having this natural interest to learn the language and talk to my grandmother to learn more.

Which one of the funny threads throughout the movie is your quest to find the language teacher. And obviously a lot of us know that there's big lack of resources to learn the Persian language. So it just has you going through these different ridiculous resources and then eventually finding different people that you can have one on one tutoring with and then getting to--So when did, when did that journey start? Was it just for this movie specifically or it had started before?

It had actually started, I'd say, a few months before I really started the film. I was taking some classes in New York, actually. And so I had this basis of knowing the alphabet, knowing what sounds the letters made and just like some formal grammar. And then when I really thought, oh, maybe I'll, maybe I'll just film this experience with my mother and grandmother and see what happens, that really set a fire under me when I realized, oh, you know, I should really be able to speak the language because I need to know these stories. And if I'm going to make a film, it's going to be really helpful in the editing process to know the language. So I thought, ok, let me see how fast I can learn to have this be a helpful tool for this process.

I'm really interested in this idea of translation as a form of censorship. We think of translation as a kind of access to what someone is saying, but forget to acknowledge that the translator's role plays a part in how we listen. I've experienced the translation of a poem, for example, and felt that something was off, or felt a moment when the translator took liberties, white-washed, or otherwise manipulated a text--even if you can't read a language, the only way to combat that ignorance is to go back to the original text. The moments when Mitra either changes Behjat's words, refuses to translate them, or disregards or disagrees with her, leaving Sierra in a partial darkness regarding semantic understanding, forces her to listen in a new way. I'd argue in these present moment, she listens with presence, with her soul, her body, her heart (akin to the listening practice of a Sufi mystic) as well as with a future ear toward understanding, an ecstatic motivation that drives her language learning process, thus her ambitions of connecting with her heritage, with the larger global Iranian community, and with Behjat, her grandmother, past her death.

Since Sierra's mother, Mitra, is also translator for Sierra (she's the only one of the three fo them who speaks both English and Persian "fluently") it is up to her what is transmitted. In other words, she could act as both barrier and door between what is said and what is understood (at least in the present moment, before Sierra later gets the transcripts). Learning the language herself is a liberating experience for Sierra, and can be for many in the diaspora who rely on the subjective experience of a parent to inform their relationship to their heritage. Suddenly, with this knowledge, the world opens up a bit. I don't think this new knowledge should negate the one that came before, however--the moments Sierra plunged herself into unknowing, and listened to Behjat's stories with something other than her intellect. When she listened with her soul, her body, her heart.

Chai and Conversations is a podcast run by Leyla Shams. One of its teaching techniques is to share poetry by poets the likes of Rumi, Hafez, Saadi, etc., guiding listeners through the poem word by word. First, the poem is read in full, without any translation. For a beginner Persian speaker, this first instance of listening might be affective, or even musical, catching a word or two here and there. What can be gleaned from the tonal register of this first recitation? What stories of emotionality from its rhythms, its pacing, its rhymes and repetitions and refrains?

While Sierra engaged with many language learning tools and resources, the one that gave her greatest motivation, it seems, is artmaking and love (or artmaking through love) even after her grandmother has passed. This echoes something Rumi felt, too, in the thirteenth century. "Whatever Mevlâna sings, whatever he feels, is in some way or the other connected with love, that is with the music of love. It is this presence of music and love that makes his poetry eternal" (Schimmell, 15). Another potential definition of poetry: the recurring failure of language to express love. There are as many moments of song, of singing, in Urich's film as there are of storytelling. Another definition of poetry: the closest language can get to music. How might we attune our listening to engage with that musical valence of language? Might a lack of semantic understanding help us listen better, in this sense? What other kind of connection might this afford us? Perhaps an eternal one.

Some of the most impactful scenes in Joonam (and by impactful, here, I might mean when feeling is most effectively transmitted to us—Urich’s audience, the viewer, the listener) are those when a translator is absent—leaving Sierra and Behjat to seek other modes of expression, of listening. This listening, I’d argue, mimics the devotional practice of sama, or “listening with the soul,” while the documentary filmmaking process generously enacts the transmission of story and storytelling to us, Urich’s audience—a practice which is reliant on not just semantic meaning, but the rhythm, music, register or “grain” of Behjat’s voice, as well as our understanding of Urich’s own relationship to her grandmother (the relationship between orator and receiver, flower and songbird, or, more truthfully, the relationship between two souls: the soul in the voice and the soul in the ear) in order for the story being told, then later, the scene in which it’s told, to achieve its full affective capacity.

I will lightly contradict, or add, to Leyla's point, with a point I make in my essay, about lack of language contributing, perhaps, to great understanding or "fluency": Sadaya khesh khesh, in Persian, is an onomatopoeic term which signifies a sound that can’t be described: white noise, the sound of the freeway, the shuffle of feet through leaves, radio static, the sound of silence, which isn’t ever really silent—the music of birdsong, of windchimes, of breeze, of breath. Is this—could this be—fluency? When you’re able to express (and learn to receive) the sound of exuberant, ecstatic love, without relying on semantic meaning? When you’ve practiced a language of love long enough that you come to be and believe it? Could fluency be simply learning to say I love you, over and over again, back and forth, like the sound of waves crashing in tandem on opposite shores? If we really tried, might we listen for it?

I think this points to affective listening, or listening with your feelings and, crucially, listening with empathy. It's easier to identify with someone in a language you yourself speak, but is it possible to still affectively listen when you don't speak that language? I think so. Each instance of listening will come with its own set of unique take-aways, but that doesn't make either less important. I'd argue that both Sierra's ability to listen beyond language, and then later, listen with language, nourished her relationship with her grandmother.

There are as many moments of song, of singing, of silence and laughter and natural sound, in Urich's film as there are moments of linguistic expression and storytelling. The Baha'i faith, members of which were historically persecuted in Iran, is also important to Urich's cultural context.
